text:
I was surprised to find that calculating the "deck score" of an array is more efficient than `hash`ing it:
```julia> @btime Day22.solve_b("<http://day22.in|day22.in>")
  675.759 ms (1324789 allocations: 212.45 MiB)

julia> @btime Day22.solve_b("<http://day22.in|day22.in>")
  130.972 ms (693296 allocations: 111.40 MiB)```
(where the first is hashing, and the second is score). Although now that I think about it the deck score is prone to collisions - I must have gotten lucky that the answer still comes out the same.

(where the first is hashing, and the second is score). Although now that I think about it the deck score is prone to collisions - I must have gotten lucky that the answer still comes out the same.

text: Was this to support the infinity checking?

elements.text: Was this to support the infinity checking?

text: Yep, pretty sure that's the bottleneck in my algorithm.
